1.verse: David Learns About Saul’s Death - Now Saul was dead. After David had defeated the Amalekites, he returned to Ziklag and stayed there two days.

2.verse: On the third day a young man from Saul’s camp came to Ziklag. To show his sadness, his clothes were torn and he had dirt on his head. He came and bowed facedown on the ground before David.

3.verse: David asked him, “Where did you come from?” The man answered, “I escaped from the Israelite camp.”

4.verse: David asked him, “What happened? Please tell me!” The man answered, “The people have run away from the battle, and many of them have fallen and are dead. Saul and his son Jonathan are dead also.”

5.verse: David asked him, “How do you know Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?”

6.verse: The young man answered, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa. There I saw Saul leaning on his spear. The Philistine chariots and the men riding in them were coming closer to Saul.

7.verse: When he looked back and saw me, he called to me. I answered him, ‘Here I am!’

8.verse: “Then Saul asked me, ‘Who are you?’ “I told him, ‘I am an Amalekite.’

9.verse: “Then Saul said to me, ‘Please come here and kill me. I am badly hurt and am almost dead already.’

10.verse: “So I went over and killed him. He had been hurt so badly I knew he couldn’t live. Then I took the crown from his head and the bracelet from his arm, and I have brought them here to you, my master.”

11.verse: Then David tore his clothes to show his sorrow, and all the men with him did also.

12.verse: They were very sad and cried and fasted until evening. They cried for Saul and his son Jonathan and for all the people of the LORD and for all the Israelites who had died in the battle.

13.verse: David Orders the Amalekite Killed - David asked the young man who brought the report, “Where are you from?” The young man answered, “I am the son of a foreigner, an Amalekite.”

14.verse: David asked him, “Why were you not afraid to kill the LORD’s appointed king?”

15.verse: Then David called one of his men and told him, “Go! Kill the Amalekite!” So the Israelite killed him.

16.verse: David had said to the Amalekite, “You are responsible for your own death. You confessed by saying, ‘I have killed the LORD’s appointed king.’”

17.verse: David’s Song About Saul and Jonathan - David sang a funeral song about Saul and his son Jonathan,

18.verse: and he ordered that the people of Judah be taught this song. It is called “The Bow,” and it is written in the Book of Jashar:

19.verse: “Israel, your leaders have been killed on the hills. How the mighty have fallen in battle!

20.verse: Don’t tell it in Gath. Don’t announce it in the streets of Ashkelon. If you do, the Philistine women will be happy. The daughters of the Philistines will rejoice.

21.verse: “May there be no dew or rain on the mountains of Gilboa, and may their fields produce no grain, because there the mighty warrior’s shield was dishonored. Saul’s shield will no longer be rubbed with oil.

22.verse: Jonathan’s bow did not fail to kill many soldiers. Saul’s sword did not fail to wound many strong men.

23.verse: “We loved Saul and Jonathan and enjoyed them while they lived. They are together even in death. They were faster than eagles. They were stronger than lions.

24.verse: “You daughters of Israel, cry for Saul. Saul clothed you with red dresses and put gold decorations on them.

25.verse: “How the mighty have fallen in battle! Jonathan is dead on Gilboa’s hills.

26.verse: I cry for you, my brother Jonathan. I enjoyed your friendship so much. Your love to me was wonderful, better than the love of women.

27.verse: “How the mighty have fallen! The weapons of war are gone.”

1.verse: David Is Made King of Judah - Later, David prayed to the LORD, saying, “Should I go up to any of the cities of Judah?” The LORD said to David, “Go.” David asked, “Where should I go?” The LORD answered, “To Hebron.”

2.verse: So David went up to Hebron with his two wives: Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel.

3.verse: David also brought his men and their families, and they all made their homes in the cities of Hebron.

4.verse: Then the men of Judah came to Hebron and appointed David king over Judah. They told David that the men of Jabesh Gilead had buried Saul.

5.verse: So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh Gilead and said to them, “The LORD bless you. You have shown loyalty to your master Saul by burying him.

6.verse: May the LORD now be loyal and true to you. I will also treat you well because you have done this.

7.verse: Now be strong and brave. Saul your master is dead, and the people of Judah have appointed me their king.”

8.verse: War Between Judah and Israel - Abner son of Ner was the commander of Saul’s army. Abner took Saul’s son Ish-Bosheth to Mahanaim

9.verse: and made him king of Gilead, Ashuri, Jezreel, Ephraim, Benjamin, and all Israel.

10.verse: Saul’s son Ish-Bosheth was forty years old when he became king over Israel, and he ruled two years. But the people of Judah followed David.

11.verse: David was king in Hebron for seven years and six months.

12.verse: Abner son of Ner and the servants of Ish-Bosheth son of Saul left Mahanaim and went to Gibeon.

13.verse: Joab son of Zeruiah and David’s men also went there and met Abner and Ish-Bosheth’s men at the pool of Gibeon. Abner’s group sat on one side of the pool; Joab’s group sat on the other.

14.verse: Abner said to Joab, “Let the young men have a contest here.” Joab said, “Yes, let them have a contest.”

15.verse: Then the men got up and were counted—twelve from the people of Benjamin for Ish-Bosheth son of Saul, and twelve from David’s men.

16.verse: Each man grabbed the one opposite him by the head and stabbed him in the side with a knife. So the men fell down together. For that reason, that place in Gibeon is called the Field of Knives.

17.verse: That day there was a terrible battle, and David’s men defeated Abner and the Israelites.

18.verse: Abner Kills Asahel - Zeruiah’s three sons, Joab, Abishai, and Asahel, were there. Now Asahel was a fast runner, as fast as a deer in the field.

19.verse: Asahel chased Abner, going straight toward him.

20.verse: Abner looked back and asked, “Is that you, Asahel?” Asahel said, “Yes, it is.”

21.verse: Then Abner said to Asahel, “Turn to your right or left and catch one of the young men and take his armor.” But Asahel refused to stop chasing him.

22.verse: Abner again said to Asahel, “Stop chasing me! If you don’t stop, I’ll have to kill you! Then I won’t be able to face your brother Joab again!”

23.verse: But Asahel refused to stop chasing Abner. So using the back end of his spear, Abner stabbed Asahel in the stomach, and the spear came out of his back. Asahel died right there, and everyone stopped when they came to the place where Asahel’s body lay.

24.verse: But Joab and Abishai continued chasing Abner. As the sun was going down, they arrived at the hill of Ammah, near Giah on the way to the desert near Gibeon.

25.verse: The men of Benjamin came to Abner, and all stood together at the top of the hill.

26.verse: Abner shouted to Joab, “Must the sword kill forever? Surely you must know this will only end in sadness! Tell the people to stop chasing their own brothers!”

27.verse: Then Joab said, “As surely as God lives, if you had not said anything, the people would have chased their brothers until morning.”

28.verse: Then Joab blew a trumpet, and his people stopped chasing the Israelites. They did not fight them anymore.

29.verse: Abner and his men marched all night through the Jordan Valley. They crossed the Jordan River, and after marching all day, arrived at Mahanaim.

30.verse: After he had stopped chasing Abner, Joab came back and gathered the people together. Asahel and nineteen of David’s men were missing.

31.verse: But David’s men had killed three hundred sixty Benjaminites who had followed Abner.

32.verse: David’s men took Asahel and buried him in the tomb of his father at Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men marched all night. The sun came up as they reached Hebron.

1.verse: There was a long war between the people who supported Saul’s family and those who supported David’s family. The supporters of David’s family became stronger and stronger, but the supporters of Saul’s family became weaker and weaker.

2.verse: David’s Sons - Sons were born to David at Hebron. The first was Amnon, whose mother was Ahinoam from Jezreel.

3.verse: The second son was Kileab, whose mother was Abigail, the widow of Nabal from Carmel. The third son was Absalom, whose mother was Maacah daughter of Talmai, the king of Geshur.

4.verse: The fourth son was Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith. The fifth son was Shephatiah, whose mother was Abital.

5.verse: The sixth son was Ithream, whose mother was Eglah, David’s wife. These sons were born to David at Hebron.

6.verse: Abner Joins David - During the war between the supporters of Saul’s family and the supporters of David’s family, Abner made himself a main leader among the supporters of Saul.

7.verse: Saul once had a slave woman named Rizpah, who was the daughter of Aiah. Ish-Bosheth said to Abner, “Why did you have sexual relations with my father’s slave woman?”

8.verse: Abner was very angry because of what Ish-Bosheth said, and he replied, “I have been loyal to Saul and his family and friends! I didn’t hand you over to David. I am not a traitor working for Judah! But now you are saying I did something wrong with this woman!

9.verse: May God help me if I don’t join David! I will make sure that what the LORD promised does happen!

10.verse: I will take the kingdom from the family of Saul and make David king of Israel and Judah, from Dan to Beersheba!”

11.verse: Ish-Bosheth couldn’t say anything to Abner, because he was afraid of him.

12.verse: Then Abner sent messengers to ask David, “Who is going to rule the land? Make an agreement with me, and I will help you unite all Israel.”

13.verse: David answered, “Good! I will make an agreement with you, but I ask you one thing. I will not meet with you unless you bring Saul’s daughter Michal to me.”

14.verse: Then David sent messengers to Saul’s son Ish-Bosheth, saying, “Give me my wife Michal. She was promised to me, and I killed a hundred Philistines to get her.”

15.verse: So Ish-Bosheth sent men to take Michal from her husband Paltiel son of Laish.

16.verse: Michal’s husband went with her, crying as he followed her to Bahurim. But Abner said to Paltiel, “Go back home.” So he went home.

17.verse: Abner sent this message to the elders of Israel: “You have been wanting to make David your king.

18.verse: Now do it! The LORD said of David, ‘Through my servant David, I will save my people Israel from the Philistines and all their enemies.’”

19.verse: Abner also said these things to the people of Benjamin. He then went to Hebron to tell David what the Benjaminites and Israel wanted to do.

20.verse: Abner came with twenty men to David at Hebron. There David prepared a feast for them.

21.verse: Abner said to David, “My master and king, I will go and bring all the Israelites to you. Then they will make an agreement with you so you will rule over all Israel as you wanted.” So David let Abner go, and he left in peace.

22.verse: Abner’s Death - Just then Joab and David’s men came from a battle, bringing many valuable things they had taken from the enemy. David had let Abner leave in peace, so he was not with David at Hebron.

23.verse: When Joab and all his army arrived at Hebron, the army said to Joab, “Abner son of Ner came to King David, and David let him leave in peace.”

24.verse: Joab came to the king and said, “What have you done? Abner came to you. Why did you let him go? Now he’s gone.

25.verse: You know Abner son of Ner! He came to trick you! He came to learn about everything you are doing!”

26.verse: After Joab left David, he sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the well of Sirah. But David did not know this.

27.verse: When Abner arrived at Hebron, Joab took him aside into the gateway. He acted as though he wanted to talk with Abner in private, but Joab stabbed him in the stomach, and Abner died. Abner had killed Joab’s brother Asahel, so Joab killed Abner to pay him back.

28.verse: Later when David heard the news, he said, “My kingdom and I are innocent forever of the death of Abner son of Ner. The LORD knows this.

29.verse: Joab and his family are responsible for this. May his family always have someone with sores or with a skin disease. May they always have someone who must lean on a crutch. May some of his family be killed in war. May they always have someone without food to eat.”

30.verse: (Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner, because he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle at Gibeon.)

31.verse: Then David said to Joab and to all the people with Joab, “Tear your clothes and put on rough cloth to show how sad you are. Cry for Abner.” King David himself followed the body of Abner.

32.verse: They buried Abner in Hebron, and David and all the people cried at Abner’s grave.

33.verse: King David sang this funeral song for Abner. “Did Abner die like a fool?

34.verse: His hands were not tied. His feet were not in chains. He fell at the hands of evil men.” Then all the people cried again for Abner.

35.verse: They came to encourage David to eat while it was still day. But he made a promise, saying, “May God punish me terribly if I eat bread or anything else before the sun sets!”

36.verse: All the people saw what happened, and they agreed with what the king was doing, just as they agreed with everything he did.

37.verse: That day all the people of Judah and Israel understood that David did not order the killing of Abner son of Ner.

38.verse: David said to his officers, “You know that a great man died today in Israel.

39.verse: Even though I am the appointed king, I feel empty. These sons of Zeruiah are too much for me. May the LORD give them the punishment they should have.”

1.verse: Ish-Bosheth’s Death - When Ish-Bosheth son of Saul heard that Abner had died at Hebron, he was shocked and all Israel became frightened.

2.verse: Two men who were captains in Saul’s army came to Ish-Bosheth. One was named Baanah, and the other was named Recab. They were the sons of Rimmon of Beeroth, who was a Benjaminite. (The town Beeroth belonged to the tribe of Benjamin.

3.verse: The people of Beeroth ran away to Gittaim, and they still live there as foreigners today.)

4.verse: (Saul’s son Jonathan had a son named Mephibosheth, who was crippled in both feet. He was five years old when the news came from Jezreel that Saul and Jonathan were dead. Mephibosheth’s nurse had picked him up and run away. But as she hurried to leave, she dropped him, and now he was lame.)

5.verse: Recab and Baanah, sons of Rimmon from Beeroth, went to Ish-Bosheth’s house in the afternoon while he was taking a nap.

6.verse: They went into the middle of the house as if to get some wheat. Ish-Bosheth was lying on his bed in his bedroom. Then Recab and Baanah stabbed him in the stomach, killed him, cut off his head, and took it with them. They escaped and traveled all night through the Jordan Valley.

7.verse: They went into the middle of the house as if to get some wheat. Ish-Bosheth was lying on his bed in his bedroom. Then Recab and Baanah stabbed him in the stomach, killed him, cut off his head, and took it with them. They escaped and traveled all night through the Jordan Valley.

8.verse: When they arrived at Hebron, they gave his head to David and said to the king, “Here is the head of Ish-Bosheth son of Saul, your enemy. He tried to kill you! Today the LORD has paid back Saul and his family for what they did to you!”

9.verse: David answered Recab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon of Beeroth, “As surely as the LORD lives, he has saved me from all trouble!

10.verse: Once a man thought he was bringing me good news. When he told me, ‘Saul is dead!’ I seized him and killed him at Ziklag. That was the reward I gave him for his news!

11.verse: So even more I must put you evil men to death because you have killed an innocent man on his own bed in his own house!”

12.verse: So David commanded his men to kill Recab and Baanah. They cut off the hands and feet of Recab and Baanah and hung them over the pool of Hebron. Then they took Ish-Bosheth’s head and buried it in Abner’s tomb at Hebron.

1.verse: David Is Made King of Israel - Then all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said to him, “Look, we are your own family.

2.verse: Even when Saul was king, you were the one who led Israel in battle. The LORD said to you, ‘You will be a shepherd for my people Israel. You will be their leader.’”

3.verse: So all the elders of Israel came to King David at Hebron, and he made an agreement with them in Hebron in the presence of the LORD. Then they poured oil on David to make him king over Israel.

4.verse: David was thirty years old when he became king, and he ruled forty years.

5.verse: He was king over Judah in Hebron for seven years and six months, and he was king over all Israel and Judah in Jerusalem for thirty-three years.

6.verse: When the king and his men went to Jerusalem to attack the Jebusites who lived there, the Jebusites said to David, “You can’t get inside our city. Even the blind and the crippled can stop you.” They thought David could not enter their city.

7.verse: But David did take the city of Jerusalem with its strong walls, and it became the City of David.

8.verse: That day David said to his men, “To defeat the Jebusites you must go through the water tunnel. Then you can reach those ‘crippled’ and ‘blind’ enemies. This is why people say, ‘The blind and the crippled may not enter the palace.’”

9.verse: So David lived in the strong, walled city and called it the City of David. David built more buildings around it, beginning where the land was filled in. He also built more buildings inside the city.

10.verse: He became stronger and stronger, because the LORD God All-Powerful was with him.

11.verse: Hiram king of the city of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedar logs, carpenters, and stonecutters. They built a palace for David.

12.verse: Then David knew that the LORD really had made him king of Israel and that the LORD had made his kingdom great because the LORD loved his people Israel.

13.verse: After he came from Hebron, David took for himself more slave women and wives in Jerusalem. More sons and daughters were born to David.

14.verse: These are the names of the sons born to David in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,

15.verse: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,

16.verse: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.

17.verse: David Defeats the Philistines - When the Philistines heard that David had been made king over Israel, all the Philistines went to look for him. But when David heard the news, he went down to the stronghold.

18.verse: The Philistines came and camped in the Valley of Rephaim.

19.verse: David asked the LORD, “Should I attack the Philistines? Will you hand them over to me?” The LORD said to David, “Go! I will certainly hand them over to you.”

20.verse: So David went to Baal Perazim and defeated the Philistines there. David said, “Like a flood of water, the LORD has broken through my enemies in front of me.” So David named the place Baal Perazim.

21.verse: The Philistines left their idols behind at Baal Perazim, so David and his men carried them away.

22.verse: Once again the Philistines came and camped at the Valley of Rephaim.

23.verse: When David prayed to the LORD, he answered, “Don’t attack the Philistines from the front. Instead, go around and attack them in front of the balsam trees.

24.verse: When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, act quickly. I, the LORD, will have gone ahead of you to defeat the Philistine army.”

25.verse: So David did what the LORD commanded. He defeated the Philistines and chased them all the way from Gibeon to Gezer.

1.verse: The Ark Is Brought to Jerusalem - David again gathered all the chosen men of Israel—thirty thousand of them.

2.verse: Then he and all his people went to Baalah in Judah to bring back the Ark of God. The Ark is called by the Name, the name of the LORD All-Powerful, whose throne is between the gold creatures with wings.

3.verse: They put the Ark of God on a new cart and brought it out of Abinadab’s house on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, sons of Abinadab, led the new cart

4.verse: which had the Ark of God on it. Ahio was walking in front of it.

5.verse: David and all the Israelites were celebrating in the presence of the LORD. They were playing wooden instruments: lyres, harps, tambourines, rattles, and cymbals.

6.verse: When David’s men came to the threshing floor of Nacon, the oxen stumbled. So Uzzah reached out to steady the Ark of God.

7.verse: The LORD was angry with Uzzah and killed him because of what he did. So Uzzah died there beside the Ark of God.

8.verse: David was angry because the LORD had killed Uzzah. Now that place is called the Punishment of Uzzah.

9.verse: David was afraid of the LORD that day, and he said, “How can the Ark of the LORD come to me now?”

10.verse: So David would not move the Ark of the LORD to be with him in Jerusalem. Instead, he took it to the house of Obed-Edom, a man from Gath.

11.verse: The Ark of the LORD stayed in Obed-Edom’s house for three months, and the LORD blessed Obed-Edom and all his family.

12.verse: The people told David, “The LORD has blessed the family of Obed-Edom and all that belongs to him, because the Ark of God is there.” So David went and brought it up from Obed-Edom’s house to Jerusalem with joy.

13.verse: When the men carrying the Ark of the LORD had walked six steps, David sacrificed a bull and a fat calf.

14.verse: Then David danced with all his might before the LORD. He had on a holy linen vest.

15.verse: David and all the Israelites shouted with joy and blew the trumpets as they brought the Ark of the LORD to the city.

16.verse: As the Ark of the LORD came into the city, Saul’s daughter Michal looked out the window. When she saw David jumping and dancing in the presence of the LORD, she hated him.

17.verse: David put up a tent for the Ark of the LORD, and then the Israelites put it in its place inside the tent. David offered whole burnt offerings and fellowship offerings before the LORD.

18.verse: When David finished offering the whole burnt offerings and the fellowship offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD All-Powerful.

19.verse: David gave a loaf of bread, a cake of dates, and a cake of raisins to every Israelite, both men and women. Then all the people went home.

20.verse: David went back to bless the people in his home, but Saul’s daughter Michal came out to meet him. She said, “With what honor the king of Israel acted today! You took off your clothes in front of the servant girls of your officers like one who takes off his clothes without shame!”

21.verse: Then David said to Michal, “I did it in the presence of the LORD. The LORD chose me, not your father or anyone from Saul’s family. The LORD appointed me to be over Israel. So I will celebrate in the presence of the LORD.

22.verse: Maybe I will lose even more honor, and maybe I will be brought down in my own opinion, but the girls you talk about will honor me!”

23.verse: And Saul’s daughter Michal had no children to the day she died.

1.verse: David Wants to Build a Temple - King David was living in his palace, and the LORD had given him peace from all his enemies around him.

2.verse: Then David said to Nathan the prophet, “Look, I am living in a palace made of cedar wood, but the Ark of God is in a tent!”

3.verse: Nathan said to the king, “Go and do what you really want to do, because the LORD is with you.”

4.verse: But that night the LORD spoke his word to Nathan,

5.verse: “Go and tell my servant David, ‘This is what the LORD says: Will you build a house for me to live in?

6.verse: From the time I brought the Israelites out of Egypt until now I have not lived in a house. I have been moving around all this time with a tent as my home.

7.verse: As I have moved with the Israelites, I have never said to the tribes, whom I commanded to take care of my people Israel, “Why haven’t you built me a house of cedar?”’

8.verse: “You must tell my servant David, ‘This is what the LORD All-Powerful says: I took you from the pasture and from tending the sheep and made you leader of my people Israel.

9.verse: I have been with you everywhere you have gone and have defeated your enemies for you. I will make you as famous as any of the great people on the earth.

10.verse: Also I will choose a place for my people Israel, and I will plant them so they can live in their own homes. They will not be bothered anymore. Wicked people will no longer bother them as they have in the past

11.verse: when I chose judges for my people Israel. But I will give you peace from all your enemies. I also tell you that I will make your descendants kings of Israel after you.

12.verse: “‘When you die and join your ancestors, I will make one of your sons the next king, and I will set up his kingdom.

13.verse: He will build a house for me, and I will let his kingdom rule always.

14.verse: I will be his father, and he will be my son. When he sins, I will use other people to punish him. They will be my whips.

15.verse: I took away my love from Saul, whom I removed before you, but I will never stop loving your son.

16.verse: But your family and your kingdom will continue always before me. Your throne will last forever.’”

17.verse: Nathan told David everything God had said in this vision.

18.verse: David Prays to God - Then King David went in and sat in front of the LORD. David said, “Lord GOD, who am I? What is my family? Why did you bring me to this point?

19.verse: But even this is not enough for you, Lord GOD. You have also made promises about my future family. This is extraordinary, Lord GOD.

20.verse: “What more can I say to you, Lord GOD, since you know me, your servant, so well!

21.verse: You have done this great thing because you said you would and because you wanted to, and you have let me know about it.

22.verse: This is why you are great, Lord GOD! There is no one like you. There is no God except you. We have heard all this ourselves!

23.verse: There is no nation like your people Israel. They are the only people on earth that God chose to be his own. You made your name well known. You did great and wonderful miracles for them. You went ahead of them and forced other nations and their gods out of the land. You freed your people from slavery in Egypt.

24.verse: You made the people of Israel your very own people forever, and, LORD, you are their God.

25.verse: “Now, LORD God, keep the promise forever that you made about my family and me, your servant. Do what you have said.

26.verse: Then you will be honored always, and people will say, ‘The LORD All-Powerful is God over Israel!’ And the family of your servant David will continue before you.

27.verse: “LORD All-Powerful, the God of Israel, you have said to me, ‘I will make your family great.’ So I, your servant, am brave enough to pray to you.

28.verse: Lord GOD, you are God, and your words are true. And you have promised these good things to me, your servant.

29.verse: Please, bless my family. Let it continue before you always. Lord GOD, you have said so. With your blessing let my family always be blessed.”

1.verse: David Wins Many Wars - Later, David defeated the Philistines, conquered them, and took the city of Metheg Ammah.

2.verse: He also defeated the people of Moab. He made them lie on the ground, and then he used a rope to measure them. Those who were measured within two rope lengths were killed, but those who were within the next rope length were allowed to live. So the people of Moab became servants of David and gave him the payment he demanded.

3.verse: David also defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, as he went to take control again at the Euphrates River.

4.verse: David captured one thousand chariots, seven thousand men who rode in chariots, and twenty thousand foot soldiers. He crippled all but a hundred of the chariot horses.

5.verse: Arameans from Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, but David killed twenty-two thousand of them.

6.verse: Then David put groups of soldiers in Damascus in Aram. The Arameans became David’s servants and gave him the payment he demanded. The LORD gave David victory everywhere he went.

7.verse: David took the shields of gold that had belonged to Hadadezer’s officers and brought them to Jerusalem.

8.verse: David also took many things made of bronze from Tebah and Berothai, which had been cities under Hadadezer’s control.

9.verse: Toi king of Hamath heard that David had defeated all the army of Hadadezer.

10.verse: So Toi sent his son Joram to greet and congratulate King David for defeating Hadadezer. (Hadadezer had been at war with Toi.) Joram brought items made of silver, gold, and bronze.

11.verse: King David gave them to the LORD, along with the silver and gold he had taken from the other nations he had defeated.

12.verse: These nations were Edom, Moab, Ammon, Philistia, and Amalek. David also gave the LORD what he had taken from Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.

13.verse: David was famous after he returned from defeating eighteen thousand Arameans in the Valley of Salt.

14.verse: He put groups of soldiers all over Edom, and all the Edomites became his servants. The LORD gave David victory everywhere he went.

15.verse: David was king over all Israel, and he did what was fair and right for all his people.

16.verse: Joab son of Zeruiah was commander over the army. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder.

17.verse: Zadok son of Ahitub and Abiathar son of Ahimelech were priests. Seraiah was the royal secretary.

18.verse: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites. And David’s sons were priests.

1.verse: David Helps Saul’s Family - David asked, “Is anyone still left in Saul’s family? I want to show kindness to that person for Jonathan’s sake!”

2.verse: Now there was a servant named Ziba from Saul’s family. So David’s servants called Ziba to him. King David said to him, “Are you Ziba?” He answered, “Yes, I am your servant.”

3.verse: The king asked, “Is anyone left in Saul’s family? I want to show God’s kindness to that person.” Ziba answered the king, “Jonathan has a son still living who is crippled in both feet.”

4.verse: The king asked Ziba, “Where is this son?” Ziba answered, “He is at the house of Makir son of Ammiel in Lo Debar.”

5.verse: Then King David had servants bring Jonathan’s son from the house of Makir son of Ammiel in Lo Debar.

6.verse: Mephibosheth, Jonathan’s son, came before David and bowed facedown on the floor. David said, “Mephibosheth!” Mephibosheth said, “I am your servant.”

7.verse: David said to him, “Don’t be afraid. I will be kind to you for your father Jonathan’s sake. I will give you back all the land of your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table.”

8.verse: Mephibosheth bowed to David again and said, “You are being very kind to me, your servant! And I am no better than a dead dog!”

9.verse: Then King David called Saul’s servant Ziba. David said to him, “I have given your master’s grandson everything that belonged to Saul and his family.

10.verse: You, your sons, and your servants will farm the land and harvest the crops. Then your family will have food to eat. But Mephibosheth, your master’s grandson, will always eat at my table.” (Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.)

11.verse: Ziba said to King David, “I, your servant, will do everything my master, the king, commands me.” So Mephibosheth ate at David’s table as if he were one of the king’s sons.

12.verse: Mephibosheth had a young son named Mica. Everyone in Ziba’s family became Mephibosheth’s servants.

13.verse: Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king’s table. And he was crippled in both feet.

1.verse: War with the Ammonites and Arameans - When Nahash king of the Ammonites died, his son Hanun became king after him.

2.verse: David said, “Nahash was loyal to me, so I will be loyal to his son Hanun.” So David sent his messengers to comfort Hanun about his father’s death. David’s officers went to the land of the Ammonites.

3.verse: But the Ammonite leaders said to Hanun, their master, “Do you think David wants to honor your father by sending men to comfort you? No! David sent them to study the city and spy it out and capture it!”

4.verse: So Hanun arrested David’s officers. To shame them he shaved off half their beards and cut off their clothes at the hips. Then he sent them away.

5.verse: When the people told David, he sent messengers to meet his officers because they were very ashamed. King David said, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back. Then come home.”

6.verse: The Ammonites knew that they had insulted David. So they hired twenty thousand Aramean foot soldiers from Beth Rehob and Zobah. They also hired the king of Maacah with a thousand men and twelve thousand men from Tob.

7.verse: When David heard about this, he sent Joab with the whole army.

8.verse: The Ammonites came out and prepared for battle at the city gate. The Arameans from Zobah and Rehob and the men from Tob and Maacah were out in the field by themselves.

9.verse: Joab saw that there were enemies both in front of him and behind him. So he chose some of the best soldiers of Israel and sent them out to fight the Arameans.

10.verse: Joab put the rest of the army under the command of Abishai, his brother. Then he sent them out to fight the Ammonites.

11.verse: Joab said to Abishai, “If the Arameans are too strong for me, you must help me. Or, if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I will help you.

12.verse: Be strong. We must fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. The LORD will do what he thinks is right.”

13.verse: Then Joab and the army with him went to attack the Arameans, and the Arameans ran away.

14.verse: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans were running away, they also ran away from Abishai and went back to their city. So Joab returned from the battle with the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.

15.verse: When the Arameans saw that Israel had defeated them, they came together into one big army.

16.verse: Hadadezer sent messengers to bring the Arameans from east of the Euphrates River, and they went to Helam. Their leader was Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army.

17.verse: When David heard about this, he gathered all the Israelites together. They crossed over the Jordan River and went to Helam. There the Arameans prepared for battle and attacked him.

18.verse: But the Arameans ran away from the Israelites. David killed seven hundred Aramean chariot drivers and forty thousand Aramean horsemen. He also killed Shobach, the commander of the Aramean army.

19.verse: When the kings who served Hadadezer saw that the Israelites had defeated them, they made peace with the Israelites and served them. And the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites again.

1.verse: David Sins with Bathsheba - In the spring, when the kings normally went out to war, David sent out Joab, his servants, and all the Israelites. They destroyed the Ammonites and attacked the city of Rabbah. But David stayed in Jerusalem.

2.verse: One evening David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of his palace. While he was on the roof, he saw a woman bathing. She was very beautiful.

3.verse: So David sent his servants to find out who she was. A servant answered, “That woman is Bathsheba daughter of Eliam. She is the wife of Uriah the Hittite.”

4.verse: So David sent messengers to bring Bathsheba to him. When she came to him, he had sexual relations with her. (Now Bathsheba had purified herself from her monthly period.) Then she went back to her house.

5.verse: But Bathsheba became pregnant and sent word to David, saying, “I am pregnant.”

6.verse: So David sent a message to Joab: “Send Uriah the Hittite to me.” And Joab sent Uriah to David.

7.verse: When Uriah came to him, David asked him how Joab was, how the soldiers were, and how the war was going.

8.verse: Then David said to Uriah, “Go home and rest.” So Uriah left the palace, and the king sent a gift to him.

9.verse: But Uriah did not go home. Instead, he slept outside the door of the palace as all the king’s officers did.

10.verse: The officers told David, “Uriah did not go home.” Then David said to Uriah, “You came from a long trip. Why didn’t you go home?”

11.verse: Uriah said to him, “The Ark and the soldiers of Israel and Judah are staying in tents. My master Joab and his officers are camping out in the fields. It isn’t right for me to go home to eat and drink and have sexual relations with my wife!”

12.verse: David said to Uriah, “Stay here today. Tomorrow I’ll send you back to the battle.” So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.

13.verse: Then David called Uriah to come to see him, so Uriah ate and drank with David. David made Uriah drunk, but he still did not go home. That evening Uriah again slept with the king’s officers.

14.verse: The next morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it by Uriah.

15.verse: In the letter David wrote, “Put Uriah on the front lines where the fighting is worst and leave him there alone. Let him be killed in battle.”

16.verse: Joab watched the city and saw where its strongest defenders were and put Uriah there.

17.verse: When the men of the city came out to fight against Joab, some of David’s men were killed. And Uriah the Hittite was one of them.

18.verse: Then Joab sent David a complete account of the war.

19.verse: Joab told the messenger, “Tell King David what happened in the war.

20.verse: After you finish, the king may be angry and ask, ‘Why did you go so near the city to fight? Didn’t you know they would shoot arrows from the city wall?

21.verse: Do you remember who killed Abimelech son of Jerub-Besheth? It was a woman on the city wall. She threw a large stone for grinding grain on Abimelech and killed him there in Thebez. Why did you go so near the wall?’ If King David asks that, tell him, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite also died.’”

22.verse: The messenger left and went to David and told him everything Joab had told him to say.

23.verse: The messenger told David, “The men of Ammon were winning. They came out and attacked us in the field, but we fought them back to the city gate.

24.verse: The archers on the city wall shot at your servants, and some of your men were killed. Your servant Uriah the Hittite also died.”

25.verse: David said to the messenger, “Say this to Joab: ‘Don’t be upset about this. The sword kills everyone the same. Make a stronger attack against the city and capture it.’ Encourage Joab with these words.”

26.verse: When Bathsheba heard that her husband was dead, she cried for him.

27.verse: After she finished her time of sadness, David sent servants to bring her to his house. She became David’s wife and gave birth to his son, but the LORD did not like what David had done.

1.verse: David’s Son Dies - The LORD sent Nathan to David. When he came to David, he said, “There were two men in a city. One was rich, but the other was poor.

2.verse: The rich man had many sheep and cattle.

3.verse: But the poor man had nothing except one little female lamb he had bought. The poor man fed the lamb, and it grew up with him and his children. It shared his food and drank from his cup and slept in his arms. The lamb was like a daughter to him.

4.verse: “Then a traveler stopped to visit the rich man. The rich man wanted to feed the traveler, but he didn’t want to take one of his own sheep or cattle. Instead, he took the lamb from the poor man and cooked it for his visitor.”

5.verse: David became very angry at the rich man. He said to Nathan, “As surely as the LORD lives, the man who did this should die!

6.verse: He must pay for the lamb four times for doing such a thing. He had no mercy!”

7.verse: Then Nathan said to David, “You are the man! This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘I appointed you king of Israel and saved you from Saul.

8.verse: I gave you his kingdom and his wives. And I made you king of Israel and Judah. And if that had not been enough, I would have given you even more.

9.verse: So why did you ignore the LORD’s command? Why did you do what he says is wrong? You killed Uriah the Hittite with the sword of the Ammonites and took his wife to be your wife!

10.verse: Now there will always be people in your family who will die by a sword, because you did not respect me; you took the wife of Uriah the Hittite for yourself!’

11.verse: “This is what the LORD says: ‘I am bringing trouble to you from your own family. While you watch, I will take your wives from you and give them to someone who is very close to you. He will have sexual relations with your wives, and everyone will know it.

12.verse: You had sexual relations with Bathsheba in secret, but I will do this so all the people of Israel can see it.’”

13.verse: Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the LORD.” Nathan answered, “The LORD has taken away your sin. You will not die.

14.verse: But what you did caused the LORD’s enemies to lose all respect for him. For this reason the son who was born to you will die.”

15.verse: Then Nathan went home. And the LORD caused the son of David and Bathsheba, Uriah’s widow, to be very sick.

16.verse: David prayed to God for the baby. David fasted and went into his house and stayed there, lying on the ground all night.

17.verse: The elders of David’s family came to him and tried to pull him up from the ground, but he refused to get up or to eat food with them.

18.verse: On the seventh day the baby died. David’s servants were afraid to tell him that the baby was dead. They said, “Look, we tried to talk to David while the baby was alive, but he refused to listen to us. If we tell him the baby is dead, he may do something awful.”

19.verse: When David saw his servants whispering, he knew that the baby was dead. So he asked them, “Is the baby dead?” They answered, “Yes, he is dead.”

20.verse: Then David got up from the floor, washed himself, put lotions on, and changed his clothes. Then he went into the LORD’s house to worship. After that, he went home and asked for something to eat. His servants gave him some food, and he ate.

21.verse: David’s servants said to him, “Why are you doing this? When the baby was still alive, you fasted and you cried. Now that the baby is dead, you get up and eat food.”

22.verse: David said, “While the baby was still alive, I fasted, and I cried. I thought, ‘Who knows? Maybe the LORD will feel sorry for me and let the baby live.’

23.verse: But now that the baby is dead, why should I fast? I can’t bring him back to life. Someday I will go to him, but he cannot come back to me.”

24.verse: Then David comforted Bathsheba his wife. He slept with her and had sexual relations with her. She became pregnant again and had another son, whom David named Solomon. The LORD loved Solomon.

25.verse: The LORD sent word through Nathan the prophet to name the baby Jedidiah, because the LORD loved the child.

26.verse: David Captures Rabbah - Joab fought against Rabbah, a royal city of the Ammonites, and he was about to capture it.

27.verse: Joab sent messengers to David and said, “I have fought against Rabbah and have captured its water supply.

28.verse: Now bring the other soldiers together and attack this city. Capture it before I capture it myself and it is called by my name!”

29.verse: So David gathered all the army and went to Rabbah and fought against it and captured it.

30.verse: David took the crown off their king’s head and had it placed on his own head. That gold crown weighed about seventy-five pounds, and it had valuable gems in it. And David took many valuable things from the city.

31.verse: He also brought out the people of the city and forced them to work with saws, iron picks, and axes. He also made them build with bricks. David did this to all the Ammonite cities. Then David and all his army returned to Jerusalem.

1.verse: Amnon and Tamar - David had a son named Absalom and a son named Amnon. Absalom had a beautiful sister named Tamar, and Amnon loved her.

2.verse: Tamar was a virgin. Amnon made himself sick just thinking about her, because he could not find any chance to be alone with her.

3.verse: Amnon had a friend named Jonadab son of Shimeah, David’s brother. Jonadab was a very clever man.

4.verse: He asked Amnon, “Son of the king, why do you look so sad day after day? Tell me what’s wrong!” Amnon told him, “I love Tamar, the sister of my half-brother Absalom.”

5.verse: Jonadab said to Amnon, “Go to bed and act as if you are sick. Then your father will come to see you. Tell him, ‘Please let my sister Tamar come in and give me food to eat. Let her make the food in front of me so I can watch and eat it from her hand.’”

6.verse: So Amnon went to bed and acted sick. When King David came in to see him, Amnon said to him, “Please let my sister Tamar come in. Let her make two of her special cakes for me while I watch. Then I will eat them from her hands.”

7.verse: David sent for Tamar in the palace, saying, “Go to your brother Amnon’s house and make some food for him.”

8.verse: So Tamar went to her brother Amnon’s house, and he was in bed. Tamar took some dough and pressed it together with her hands. She made some special cakes while Amnon watched. Then she baked them.

9.verse: Next she took the pan and served him, but he refused to eat. He said to his servants, “All of you, leave me alone!” So they all left him alone.

10.verse: Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food into the bedroom so I may eat from your hand.” Tamar took the cakes she had made and brought them to her brother Amnon in the bedroom.

11.verse: She went to him so he could eat from her hands, but Amnon grabbed her. He said, “Sister, come and have sexual relations with me.”

12.verse: Tamar said to him, “No, brother! Don’t force me! This should never be done in Israel! Don’t do this shameful thing!

13.verse: I could never get rid of my shame! And you will be like the shameful fools in Israel! Please talk with the king, and he will let you marry me.”

14.verse: But Amnon refused to listen to her. He was stronger than she was, so he forced her to have sexual relations with him.

15.verse: After that, Amnon hated Tamar. He hated her more than he had loved her before. Amnon said to her, “Get up and leave!”

16.verse: Tamar said to him, “No! Sending me away would be worse than what you’ve already done!” But he refused to listen to her.

17.verse: He called his young servant back in and said, “Get this woman out of here and away from me! Lock the door after her.”

18.verse: So his servant led her out of the room and bolted the door after her. Tamar was wearing a special robe with long sleeves, because the king’s virgin daughters wore this kind of robe.

19.verse: To show how upset she was, Tamar put ashes on her head and tore her special robe and put her hand on her head. Then she went away, crying loudly.

20.verse: Absalom, Tamar’s brother, said to her, “Has Amnon, your brother, forced you to have sexual relations with him? For now, sister, be quiet. He is your half-brother. Don’t let this upset you so much!” So Tamar lived in her brother Absalom’s house and was sad and lonely.

21.verse: When King David heard the news, he was very angry.

22.verse: Absalom did not say a word, good or bad, to Amnon. But he hated Amnon for disgracing his sister Tamar.

23.verse: Absalom’s Revenge - Two years later Absalom had some men come to Baal Hazor, near Ephraim, to cut the wool from his sheep. Absalom invited all the king’s sons to come also.

24.verse: Absalom went to the king and said, “I have men coming to cut the wool. Please come with your officers and join me.”

25.verse: King David said to Absalom, “No, my son. We won’t all go, because it would be too much trouble for you.” Although Absalom begged David, he would not go, but he did give his blessing.

26.verse: Absalom said, “If you don’t want to come, then please let my brother Amnon come with us.” King David asked, “Why should he go with you?”

27.verse: Absalom kept begging David until he let Amnon and all the king’s sons go with Absalom.

28.verse: Then Absalom instructed his servants, “Watch Amnon. When he is drunk, I will tell you, ‘Kill Amnon.’ Right then, kill him! Don’t be afraid, because I have commanded you! Be strong and brave!”

29.verse: So Absalom’s young men killed Amnon as Absalom commanded, but all of David’s other sons got on their mules and escaped.

30.verse: While the king’s sons were on their way, the news came to David, “Absalom has killed all of the king’s sons! Not one of them is left alive!”

31.verse: King David tore his clothes and lay on the ground to show his sadness. All his servants standing nearby tore their clothes also.

32.verse: Jonadab son of Shimeah, David’s brother, said to David, “Don’t think all the young men, your sons, are killed. No, only Amnon is dead! Absalom has planned this ever since Amnon forced his sister Tamar to have sexual relations with him.

33.verse: My master and king, don’t think that all of the king’s sons are dead. Only Amnon is dead!”

34.verse: In the meantime Absalom had run away. A guard standing on the city wall saw many people coming from the other side of the hill.

35.verse: So Jonadab said to King David, “Look, I was right! The king’s sons are coming!”

36.verse: As soon as Jonadab had said this, the king’s sons arrived, crying loudly. David and all his servants began crying also.

37.verse: David cried for his son every day. But Absalom ran away to Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur.

38.verse: After Absalom ran away to Geshur, he stayed there for three years.

39.verse: When King David got over Amnon’s death, he missed Absalom greatly.

1.verse: Joab Sends a Wise Woman to David - Joab son of Zeruiah knew that King David missed Absalom very much.

2.verse: So Joab sent messengers to Tekoa to bring a wise woman from there. He said to her, “Pretend to be very sad. Put on funeral clothes and don’t put lotion on yourself. Act like a woman who has been crying many days for someone who died.

3.verse: Then go to the king and say these words.” Then Joab told her what to say.

4.verse: So the woman from Tekoa spoke to the king. She bowed facedown on the ground to show respect and said, “My king, help me!”

5.verse: King David asked her, “What is the matter?” The woman said, “I am a widow; my husband is dead.

6.verse: I had two sons. They were out in the field fighting, and no one was there to stop them. So one son killed the other son.

7.verse: Now all the family group is against me. They said to me, ‘Bring the son who killed his brother so we may kill him for killing his brother. That way we will also get rid of the one who would receive what belonged to his father.’ My son is like the last spark of a fire. He is all I have left. If they kill him, my husband’s name and property will be gone from the earth.”

8.verse: Then the king said to the woman, “Go home. I will take care of this for you.”

9.verse: The woman of Tekoa said to him, “Let the blame be on me and my father’s family. My master and king, you and your throne are innocent.”

10.verse: King David said, “Bring me anyone who says anything bad to you. Then he won’t bother you again.”

11.verse: The woman said, “Please promise in the name of the LORD your God. Then my relative who has the duty of punishing a murderer won’t add to the destruction by killing my son.” David said, “As surely as the LORD lives, no one will hurt your son. Not one hair from his head will fall to the ground.”

12.verse: The woman said, “Let me say something to you, my master and king.” The king said, “Speak.”

13.verse: Then the woman said, “Why have you decided this way against the people of God? When you judge this way, you show that you are guilty for not bringing back your son who was forced to leave home.

14.verse: We will all die someday. We’re like water spilled on the ground; no one can gather it back. But God doesn’t take away life. Instead, he plans ways that those who have been sent away will not have to stay away from him!

15.verse: My master and king, I came to say this to you because the people have made me afraid! I thought, ‘Let me talk to the king. Maybe he will do what I ask.

16.verse: Maybe he will listen. Perhaps he will save me from those who want to keep both me and my son from getting what God gave us.’

17.verse: “Now I say, ‘May the words of my master the king give me rest. Like an angel of God, you know what is good and what is bad. May the LORD your God be with you!’”

18.verse: Then King David said, “Do not hide the truth. Answer me one question.” The woman said, “My master the king, please ask your question.”

19.verse: The king said, “Did Joab tell you to say all these things?” The woman answered, “As you live, my master the king, no one could avoid that question. You are right. Your servant Joab did tell me to say these things.

20.verse: Joab did it so you would see things differently. My master, you are wise like an angel of God who knows everything that happens on earth.”

21.verse: Absalom Returns to Jerusalem - The king said to Joab, “Look, I will do what I promised. Bring back the young man Absalom.”

22.verse: Joab bowed facedown on the ground and blessed the king. Then he said, “Today I know you are pleased with me, because you have done what I asked.”

23.verse: Then Joab got up and went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.

24.verse: But King David said, “Absalom must go to his own house. He may not come to see me.” So Absalom went to his own house and did not go to see the king.

25.verse: Absalom was greatly praised for his handsome appearance. No man in Israel was as handsome as he. No blemish was on him from his head to his foot.

26.verse: At the end of every year, Absalom would cut his hair, because it became too heavy. When he weighed it, it would weigh about five pounds by the royal measure.

27.verse: Absalom had three sons and one daughter. His daughter’s name was also Tamar, and she was a beautiful woman.

28.verse: Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two full years without seeing King David.

29.verse: Then Absalom sent for Joab so he could send him to the king, but Joab would not come. Absalom sent a message a second time, but Joab still refused to come.

30.verse: Then Absalom said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley growing there. Go burn it.” So Absalom’s servants set fire to Joab’s field.

31.verse: Then Joab went to Absalom’s house and said to him, “Why did your servants burn my field?”

32.verse: Absalom said to Joab, “I sent a message to you, asking you to come here. I wanted to send you to the king to ask him why he brought me home from Geshur. It would have been better for me to stay there! Now let me see the king. If I have sinned, he can put me to death!”

33.verse: So Joab went to the king and told him Absalom’s words. Then the king called for Absalom. Absalom came and bowed facedown on the ground before the king, and the king kissed him.

1.verse: Absalom Plans to Take David’s Kingdom - After this, Absalom got a chariot and horses for himself and fifty men to run before him.

2.verse: Absalom would get up early and stand near the city gate. Anyone who had a problem for the king to settle would come here. When someone came, Absalom would call out and say, “What city are you from?” The person would answer, “I’m from one of the tribes of Israel.”

3.verse: Then Absalom would say, “Look, your claims are right, but the king has no one to listen to you.”

4.verse: Absalom would also say, “I wish someone would make me judge in this land! Then people with problems could come to me, and I could help them get justice.”

5.verse: People would come near Absalom to bow to him. When they did, Absalom would reach out his hand and take hold of them and kiss them.

6.verse: Absalom did that to all the Israelites who came to King David for decisions. In this way, Absalom stole the hearts of all Israel.

7.verse: After four years Absalom said to King David, “Please let me go to Hebron. I want to carry out my promise that I made to the LORD

8.verse: while I was living in Geshur in Aram. I said, ‘If the LORD takes me back to Jerusalem, I will worship him in Hebron.’”

9.verse: The king said, “Go in peace.” So Absalom went to Hebron.

10.verse: But he sent secret messengers through all the tribes of Israel. They told the people, “When you hear the trumpets, say this: ‘Absalom is the king at Hebron!’”

11.verse: Absalom had invited two hundred men to go with him. So they went from Jerusalem with him, but they didn’t know what he was planning.

12.verse: While Absalom was offering sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel, one of the people who advised David, to come from his hometown of Giloh. So Absalom’s plans were working very well. More and more people began to support him.

13.verse: A messenger came to David, saying, “The Israelites are giving their loyalty to Absalom.”

14.verse: Then David said to all his officers who were with him in Jerusalem, “We must leave quickly! If we don’t, we won’t be able to get away from Absalom. We must hurry before he catches us and destroys us and kills the people of Jerusalem.”

15.verse: The king’s officers said to him, “We will do anything you say.”

16.verse: The king set out with everyone in his house, but he left ten slave women to take care of the palace.

17.verse: The king left with all his people following him, and they stopped at a house far away.

18.verse: All the king’s servants passed by him—the Kerethites and Pelethites, all those from Gath, and the six hundred men who had followed him.

19.verse: The king said to Ittai, a man from Gath, “Why are you also going with us? Turn back and stay with King Absalom because you are a foreigner. This is not your homeland.

20.verse: You joined me only a short time ago. Should I make you wander with us when I don’t even know where I’m going? Turn back and take your brothers with you. May kindness and loyalty be shown to you.”

21.verse: But Ittai said to the king, “As surely as the LORD lives and as you live, I will stay with you, whether it means life or death.”

22.verse: David said to Ittai, “Go, march on.” So Ittai from Gath and all his people with their children marched on.

23.verse: All the people cried loudly as everyone passed by. King David crossed the Kidron Valley, and then all the people went on to the desert.

24.verse: Zadok and all the Levites with him carried the Ark of the Agreement with God. They set it down, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people had left the city.

25.verse: The king said to Zadok, “Take the Ark of God back into the city. If the LORD is pleased with me, he will bring me back and will let me see both it and Jerusalem again.

26.verse: But if the LORD says he is not pleased with me, I am ready. He can do what he wants with me.”

27.verse: The king also said to Zadok the priest, “Aren’t you a seer? Go back to the city in peace and take your son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan with you.

28.verse: I will wait near the crossings into the desert until I hear from you.”

29.verse: So Zadok and Abiathar took the Ark of God back to Jerusalem and stayed there.

30.verse: David went up the Mount of Olives, crying as he went. He covered his head and went barefoot. All the people with David covered their heads also and cried as they went.

31.verse: Someone told David, “Ahithophel is one of the people with Absalom who made secret plans against you.” So David prayed, “LORD, please make Ahithophel’s advice foolish.”

32.verse: When David reached the top of the mountain where people used to worship God, Hushai the Arkite came to meet him. Hushai’s coat was torn, and there was dirt on his head to show how sad he was.

33.verse: David said to Hushai, “If you go with me, you will be just one more person for me to take care of.

34.verse: But if you return to the city, you can make Ahithophel’s advice useless. Tell Absalom, ‘I am your servant, my king. In the past I served your father, but now I will serve you.’

35.verse: The priests Zadok and Abiathar will be with you. Tell them everything you hear in the royal palace.

36.verse: Zadok’s son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan are with them. Send them to tell me everything you hear.”

37.verse: So David’s friend Hushai entered Jerusalem just as Absalom arrived.

1.verse: Ziba Meets David - When David had passed a short way over the top of the Mount of Olives, Ziba, Mephibosheth’s servant, met him. Ziba had a row of donkeys loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred cakes of raisins, one hundred cakes of figs, and leather bags full of wine.

2.verse: The king asked Ziba, “What are these things for?” Ziba answered, “The donkeys are for your family to ride. The bread and cakes of figs are for the servants to eat. And the wine is for anyone to drink who might become weak in the desert.”

3.verse: The king asked, “Where is Mephibosheth?” Ziba answered him, “Mephibosheth is staying in Jerusalem because he thinks, ‘Today the Israelites will give my father’s kingdom back to me!’”

4.verse: Then the king said to Ziba, “All right. Everything that belonged to Mephibosheth, I now give to you!” Ziba said, “I bow to you. I hope I will always be able to please you.”

5.verse: Shimei Curses David - As King David came to Bahurim, a man came out and cursed him. He was from Saul’s family group, and his name was Shimei son of Gera.

6.verse: He threw stones at David and his officers, but the people and soldiers gathered all around David.

7.verse: Shimei cursed David, saying, “Get out, get out, you murderer, you troublemaker.

8.verse: The LORD is punishing you for the people in Saul’s family you killed! You took Saul’s place as king, but now the LORD has given the kingdom to your son Absalom! Now you are ruined because you are a murderer!”

9.verse: Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse you, the king? Let me go over and cut off his head!”

10.verse: But the king answered, “This does not concern you, sons of Zeruiah! If he is cursing me because the LORD told him to, who can question him?”

11.verse: David also said to Abishai and all his officers, “My own son is trying to kill me! This man is a Benjaminite and has more right to kill me! Leave him alone, and let him curse me because the LORD told him to do this.

12.verse: Maybe the LORD will see my misery and repay me with something good for Shimei’s curses today!”

13.verse: So David and his men went on down the road, but Shimei followed on the nearby hillside. He kept cursing David and throwing stones and dirt at him.

14.verse: When the king and all his people arrived at the Jordan, they were very tired, so they rested there.

15.verse: Meanwhile, Absalom, Ahithophel, and all the Israelites arrived at Jerusalem.

16.verse: David’s friend Hushai the Arkite came to Absalom and said to him, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”

17.verse: Absalom asked, “Why are you not loyal to your friend David? Why didn’t you leave Jerusalem with your friend?”

18.verse: Hushai said, “I belong to the one chosen by the LORD and by these people and everyone in Israel. I will stay with you.

19.verse: In the past I served your father. So whom should I serve now? David’s son! I will serve you as I served him.”

20.verse: Ahithophel’s Advice - Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Tell us what we should do.”

21.verse: Ahithophel said, “Your father left behind some of his slave women to take care of the palace. Have sexual relations with them. Then all Israel will hear that your father is your enemy, and all your people will be encouraged to give you more support.”

22.verse: So they put up a tent for Absalom on the roof of the palace where everyone in Israel could see it. And Absalom had sexual relations with his father’s slave women.

23.verse: At that time people thought Ahithophel’s advice was as reliable as God’s own word. Both David and Absalom thought it was that reliable.

1.verse: Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men and chase David tonight.

2.verse: I’ll catch him while he is tired and weak, and I’ll frighten him so all his people will run away. But I’ll kill only King David.

3.verse: Then I’ll bring everyone back to you. If the man you are looking for is dead, everyone else will return safely.”

4.verse: This plan seemed good to Absalom and to all the leaders of Israel.

5.verse: But Absalom said, “Now call Hushai the Arkite, so I can hear what he says.”

6.verse: When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said to him, “This is the plan Ahithophel gave. Should we follow it? If not, tell us.”

7.verse: Hushai said to Absalom, “Ahithophel’s advice is not good this time.”

8.verse: Hushai added, “You know your father and his men are strong. They are as angry as a bear that is robbed of its cubs. Your father is a skilled fighter. He won’t stay all night with the army.

9.verse: He is probably already hiding in a cave or some other place. If the first attack fails, people will hear the news and think, ‘Absalom’s followers are losing!’

10.verse: Then even the men who are as brave as lions will be frightened, because all the Israelites know your father is a fighter. They know his men are brave!

11.verse: “This is what I suggest: Gather all the Israelites from Dan to Beersheba. There will be as many people as grains of sand by the sea. Then you yourself must go into the battle.

12.verse: We will go to David wherever he is hiding. We will fall on him as dew falls on the ground. We will kill him and all of his men so that no one will be left alive.

13.verse: If David escapes into a city, all the Israelites will bring ropes to that city and pull it into the valley. Not a stone will be left!”

14.verse: Absalom and all the Israelites said, “The advice of Hushai the Arkite is better than that of Ahithophel.” (The LORD had planned to destroy the good advice of Ahithophel so the LORD could bring disaster on Absalom.)

15.verse: Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, what Ahithophel had suggested to Absalom and the elders of Israel. He also reported to them what he himself had suggested. Hushai said,

16.verse: “Quickly! Send a message to David. Tell him not to stay tonight at the crossings into the desert but to cross over the Jordan River at once. If he crosses the river, he and all his people won’t be destroyed.”

17.verse: Jonathan and Ahimaaz were waiting at En Rogel. They did not want to be seen going into the city, so a servant girl would go out to them and give them messages. Then Jonathan and Ahimaaz would go and tell King David.

18.verse: But a boy saw Jonathan and Ahimaaz and told Absalom. So Jonathan and Ahimaaz left quickly and went to a man’s house in Bahurim. He had a well in his courtyard, and they climbed down into it.

19.verse: The man’s wife spread a sheet over the opening of the well and covered it with grain. No one could tell that anyone was hiding there.

20.verse: Absalom’s servants came to the woman at the house and asked, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” She said to them, “They have already crossed the brook.” Absalom’s servants then went to look for Jonathan and Ahimaaz, but they could not find them. So they went back to Jerusalem.

21.verse: After Absalom’s servants left, Jonathan and Ahimaaz climbed out of the well and went to tell King David. They said, “Hurry, cross over the river! Ahithophel has said these things against you!”

22.verse: So David and all his people crossed the Jordan River. By dawn, everyone had crossed the Jordan.

23.verse: When Ahithophel saw that the Israelites did not accept his advice, he saddled his donkey and went to his hometown. He left orders for his family and property, and then he hanged himself. He died and was buried in his father’s tomb.

24.verse: War Between David and Absalom - David arrived at Mahanaim. And Absalom and all his Israelites crossed over the Jordan River.

25.verse: Absalom had made Amasa captain of the army instead of Joab. Amasa was the son of a man named Jether the Ishmaelite. Amasa’s mother was Abigail daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah, Joab’s mother.

26.verse: Absalom and the Israelites camped in the land of Gilead.

27.verse: Shobi, Makir, and Barzillai were at Mahanaim when David arrived. Shobi son of Nahash was from the Ammonite town of Rabbah. Makir son of Ammiel was from Lo Debar, and Barzillai was from Rogelim in Gilead.

28.verse: They brought beds, bowls, clay pots, wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, small peas,

29.verse: honey, milk curds, sheep, and cheese made from cows’ milk for David and his people. They said, “The people are hungry and tired and thirsty in the desert.”

1.verse: David counted his men and placed over them commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds.

2.verse: He sent the troops out in three groups. Joab commanded one-third of the men. Joab’s brother Abishai son of Zeruiah commanded another third. And Ittai from Gath commanded the last third. King David said to them, “I will also go with you.”

3.verse: But the men said, “You must not go with us! If we run away in the battle, Absalom’s men won’t care. Even if half of us are killed, Absalom’s men won’t care. But you’re worth ten thousand of us! You can help us most by staying in the city.”

4.verse: The king said to his people, “I will do what you think is best.” So the king stood at the side of the gate as the army went out in groups of a hundred and a thousand.

5.verse: The king commanded Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, “Be gentle with young Absalom for my sake.” Everyone heard the king’s orders to the commanders about Absalom.

6.verse: David’s army went out into the field against Absalom’s Israelites, and they fought in the forest of Ephraim.

7.verse: There David’s army defeated the Israelites. Many died that day—twenty thousand men.

8.verse: The battle spread through all the country, but that day more men died in the forest than in the fighting.

9.verse: Absalom Dies - Then Absalom happened to meet David’s troops. As Absalom was riding his mule, it went under the thick branches of a large oak tree. Absalom’s head got caught in the tree, and his mule ran out from under him. So Absalom was left hanging above the ground.

10.verse: When one of the men saw it happen, he told Joab, “I saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree!”

11.verse: Joab said to him, “You saw him? Why didn’t you kill him and let him fall to the ground? I would have given you a belt and four ounces of silver!”

12.verse: The man answered, “I wouldn’t touch the king’s son even if you gave me twenty-five pounds of silver. We heard the king command you, Abishai, and Ittai, ‘Be careful not to hurt young Absalom.’

13.verse: If I had killed him, the king would have found out, and you would not have protected me!”

14.verse: Joab said, “I won’t waste time here with you!” Absalom was still alive in the oak tree, so Joab took three spears and stabbed him in the heart.

15.verse: Ten young men who carried Joab’s armor also gathered around Absalom and struck him and killed him.

16.verse: Then Joab blew the trumpet, so the troops stopped chasing the Israelites.

17.verse: Then Joab’s men took Absalom’s body and threw it into a large pit in the forest and filled the pit with many stones. All the Israelites ran away to their homes.

18.verse: When Absalom was alive, he had set up a pillar for himself in the King’s Valley. He said, “I have no son to keep my name alive.” So he named the pillar after himself, and it is called Absalom’s Monument even today.

19.verse: Ahimaaz son of Zadok said to Joab, “Let me run and take the news to King David. I’ll tell him the LORD has saved him from his enemies.”

20.verse: Joab answered Ahimaaz, “No, you are not the one to take the news today. You may do it another time, but do not take it today, because the king’s son is dead.”

21.verse: Then Joab said to a man from Cush, “Go, tell the king what you have seen.” The Cushite bowed to Joab and ran to tell David.

22.verse: But Ahimaaz son of Zadok begged Joab again, “No matter what happens, please let me go along with the Cushite!” Joab said, “Son, why do you want to carry the news? You won’t get any reward.”

23.verse: Ahimaaz answered, “No matter what happens, I will run.” So Joab said to Ahimaaz, “Run!” Then Ahimaaz ran by way of the Jordan Valley and passed the Cushite.

24.verse: David was sitting between the inner and outer gates of the city. The watchman went up to the roof of the gate by the walls, and as he looked up, he saw a man running alone.

25.verse: He shouted the news to the king. The king said, “If he is alone, he is bringing good news!” The man came nearer and nearer to the city.

26.verse: Then the watchman saw another man running, and he called to the gatekeeper, “Look! Another man is running alone!” The king said, “He is also bringing good news!”

27.verse: The watchman said, “I think the first man runs like Ahimaaz son of Zadok.” The king said, “Ahimaaz is a good man. He must be bringing good news!”

28.verse: Then Ahimaaz called a greeting to the king. He bowed facedown on the ground before the king and said, “Praise the LORD your God! The LORD has defeated those who were against you, my king.”

29.verse: The king asked, “Is young Absalom all right?” Ahimaaz answered, “When Joab sent me, I saw some great excitement, but I don’t know what it was.”

30.verse: The king said, “Step over here and wait.” So Ahimaaz stepped aside and stood there.

31.verse: Then the Cushite arrived. He said, “Master and king, hear the good news! Today the LORD has punished those who were against you!”

32.verse: The king asked the Cushite, “Is young Absalom all right?” The Cushite answered, “May your enemies and all who come to hurt you be like that young man!”

33.verse: Then the king was very upset, and he went to the room over the city gate and cried. As he went, he cried out, “My son Absalom, my son Absalom! I wish I had died and not you. Absalom, my son, my son!”

1.verse: Joab Scolds David - People told Joab, “Look, the king is sad and crying because of Absalom.”

2.verse: David’s army had won the battle that day. But it became a very sad day for all the people, because they heard that the king was very sad for his son.

3.verse: The people came into the city quietly that day. They were like an army that had been defeated in battle and had run away.

4.verse: The king covered his face and cried loudly, “My son Absalom! Absalom, my son, my son!”

5.verse: Joab went into the king’s house and said, “Today you have shamed all your men. They saved your life and the lives of your sons, daughters, wives, and slave women.

6.verse: You have shamed them because you love those who hate you, and you hate those who love you. Today you have made it clear that your commanders and men mean nothing to you. What if Absalom had lived and all of us were dead? I can see you would be pleased.

7.verse: Now go out and encourage your servants. I swear by the LORD that if you don’t go out, no man will be left with you by tonight! That will be worse than all the troubles you have had from your youth until today.”

8.verse: So the king went to the city gate. When the news spread that the king was at the gate, everyone came to see him. David Goes Back to Jerusalem - All the Israelites who had followed Absalom had run away to their homes.

9.verse: People in all the tribes of Israel began to argue, saying, “The king saved us from the Philistines and our other enemies, but he left the country because of Absalom.

10.verse: We appointed Absalom to rule us, but now he has died in battle. We should make David the king again.”

11.verse: King David sent a message to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, that said, “Speak to the elders of Judah. Say, ‘Even in my house I have heard what all the Israelites are saying. So why are you the last tribe to bring the king back to his palace?

12.verse: You are my brothers, my own family. Why are you the last tribe to bring back the king?’

13.verse: And say to Amasa, ‘You are part of my own family. May God punish me terribly if I don’t make you commander of the army in Joab’s place!’”

14.verse: David touched the hearts of all the people of Judah at once. They sent a message to the king that said, “Return with all your men.”

15.verse: Then the king returned as far as the Jordan River. The men of Judah came to Gilgal to meet him and to bring him across the Jordan.

16.verse: Shimei son of Gera, a Benjaminite who lived in Bahurim, hurried down with the men of Judah to meet King David.

17.verse: With Shimei came a thousand Benjaminites. Ziba, the servant from Saul’s family, also came, bringing his fifteen sons and twenty servants with him. They all hurried to the Jordan River to meet the king.

18.verse: The people went across the Jordan to help bring the king’s family back to Judah and to do whatever the king wanted. As the king was crossing the river, Shimei son of Gera came to him and bowed facedown on the ground in front of the king.

19.verse: He said to the king, “My master, don’t hold me guilty. Don’t remember the wrong I did when you left Jerusalem! Don’t hold it against me.

20.verse: I know I have sinned. That is why I am the first person from Joseph’s family to come down and meet you today, my master and king!”

21.verse: But Abishai son of Zeruiah said, “Shimei should die because he cursed you, the LORD’s appointed king!”

22.verse: David said, “This does not concern you, sons of Zeruiah! Today you’re against me! No one will be put to death in Israel today. Today I know I am king over Israel!”

23.verse: Then the king promised Shimei, “You won’t die.”

24.verse: Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson, also went down to meet King David. Mephibosheth had not cared for his feet, cut his beard, or washed his clothes from the time the king had left Jerusalem until he returned safely.

25.verse: When Mephibosheth came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, “Mephibosheth, why didn’t you go with me?”

26.verse: He answered, “My master, my servant Ziba tricked me! I said to Ziba, ‘I am crippled, so saddle a donkey. Then I will ride it so I can go with the king.’

27.verse: But he lied about me to you. You, my master and king, are like an angel from God. Do what you think is good.

28.verse: You could have killed all my grandfather’s family. Instead, you put me with those people who eat at your own table. So I don’t have a right to ask anything more from the king!”

29.verse: The king said to him, “Don’t say anything more. I have decided that you and Ziba will divide the land.”

30.verse: Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let Ziba take all the land now that my master the king has arrived safely home.”

31.verse: Barzillai of Gilead came down from Rogelim to cross the Jordan River with the king.

32.verse: Barzillai was a very old man, eighty years old. He had taken care of the king when David was staying at Mahanaim, because Barzillai was a very rich man.

33.verse: David said to Barzillai, “Cross the river with me. Come with me to Jerusalem, and I will take care of you.”
