34.verse: But Barzillai answered the king, “Do you know how old I am? Do you think I can go with you to Jerusalem?

35.verse: I am eighty years old! I am too old to taste what I eat or drink. I am too old to hear the voices of men and women singers. Why should you be bothered with me?

36.verse: I am not worthy of a reward from you, but I will cross the Jordan River with you.

37.verse: Then let me go back so I may die in my own city near the grave of my father and mother. But here is Kimham, your servant. Let him go with you, my master and king. Do with him whatever you want.”

38.verse: The king answered, “Kimham will go with me. I will do for him anything you wish, and I will do anything for you that you wish.”

39.verse: The king kissed Barzillai and blessed him. Then Barzillai returned home, and the king and all the people crossed the Jordan.

40.verse: When the king crossed over to Gilgal, Kimham went with him. All the troops of Judah and half the troops of Israel led David across the river.

41.verse: Soon all the Israelites came to the king and said to him, “Why did our relatives, the people of Judah, steal you away? Why did they bring you and your family across the Jordan River with your men?”

42.verse: All the people of Judah answered the Israelites, “We did this because the king is our close relative. Why are you angry about it? We have not eaten food at the king’s expense or taken anything for ourselves!”

43.verse: The Israelites answered the people of Judah, “We have ten tribes in the kingdom, so we have more right to David than you do! But you ignored us! We were the first ones to talk about bringing our king back!” But the people of Judah spoke even more unkindly than the people of Israel.

1.verse: Sheba Leads Israel Away from David - It happened that a troublemaker named Sheba son of Bicri from the tribe of Benjamin was there. He blew the trumpet and said: “We have no share in David! We have no part in the son of Jesse! People of Israel, let’s go home!”

2.verse: So all the Israelites left David and followed Sheba son of Bicri. But the people of Judah stayed with their king all the way from the Jordan River to Jerusalem.

3.verse: David came back to his palace in Jerusalem. He had left ten of his slave women there to take care of the palace. Now he put them in a locked house. He gave them food, but he did not have sexual relations with them. So they lived like widows until they died.

4.verse: The king said to Amasa, “Tell the men of Judah to meet with me in three days, and you must also be here.”

5.verse: So Amasa went to call the men of Judah together, but he took more time than the king had said.

6.verse: David said to Abishai, “Sheba son of Bicri is more dangerous to us than Absalom was. Take my men and chase him before he finds walled cities and escapes from us.”

7.verse: So Joab’s men, the Kerethites and the Pelethites, and all the soldiers went with Abishai. They went out from Jerusalem to chase Sheba son of Bicri.

8.verse: When Joab and the army came to the great rock at Gibeon, Amasa came out to meet them. Joab was wearing his uniform, and at his waist he wore a belt that held his sword in its case. As Joab stepped forward, his sword fell out of its case.

9.verse: Joab asked Amasa, “Brother, is everything all right with you?” Then with his right hand he took Amasa by the beard to kiss him.

10.verse: Amasa was not watching the sword in Joab’s hand. So Joab pushed the sword into Amasa’s stomach, causing Amasa’s insides to spill onto the ground. Joab did not have to stab Amasa again; he was already dead. Then Joab and his brother Abishai continued to chase Sheba son of Bicri.

11.verse: One of Joab’s young men stood by Amasa’s body and said, “Everyone who is for Joab and David should follow Joab!”

12.verse: Amasa lay in the middle of the road, covered with his own blood. When the young man saw that everyone was stopping to look at the body, he dragged it from the road, laid it in a field, and put a cloth over it.

13.verse: After Amasa’s body was taken off the road, all the men followed Joab to chase Sheba son of Bicri.

14.verse: Sheba went through all the tribes of Israel to Abel Beth Maacah. All the Berites also came together and followed him.

15.verse: So Joab and his men came to Abel Beth Maacah and surrounded it. They piled dirt up against the city wall, and they began hacking at the walls to bring them down.

16.verse: But a wise woman shouted out from the city, “Listen! Listen! Tell Joab to come here. I want to talk to him!”

17.verse: So Joab came near her. She asked him, “Are you Joab?” He answered, “Yes, I am.” Then she said, “Listen to what I say.” Joab said, “I’m listening.”

18.verse: Then the woman said, “In the past people would say, ‘Ask for advice at Abel,’ and the problem would be solved.

19.verse: I am one of the peaceful, loyal people of Israel. You are trying to destroy an important city of Israel. Why must you destroy what belongs to the LORD?”

20.verse: Joab answered, “I would prefer not to destroy or ruin anything!

21.verse: That is not what I want. But there is a man here from the mountains of Ephraim, who is named Sheba son of Bicri. He has turned against King David. If you bring him to me, I will leave the city alone.” The woman said to Joab, “His head will be thrown over the wall to you.”

22.verse: Then the woman spoke very wisely to all the people of the city. They cut off the head of Sheba son of Bicri and threw it over the wall to Joab. So he blew the trumpet, and the army left the city. Every man returned home, and Joab went back to the king in Jerusalem.

23.verse: Joab was commander of all the army of Israel. Benaiah son of Jehoiada led the Kerethites and Pelethites.

24.verse: Adoniram was in charge of the men who were forced to do hard work. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder.

25.verse: Sheba was the royal secretary. Zadok and Abiathar were the priests,

26.verse: and Ira the Jairite was David’s priest.

1.verse: The Gibeonites Punish Saul’s Family - During the time David was king, there was a shortage of food that lasted for three years. So David prayed to the LORD. The LORD answered, “Saul and his family of murderers are the reason for this shortage, because he killed the Gibeonites.”

2.verse: (Now the Gibeonites were not Israelites; they were a group of Amorites who were left alive. The Israelites had promised not to hurt the Gibeonites, but Saul had tried to kill them, because he was eager to help the people of Israel and Judah.) King David called the Gibeonites together and spoke to them.

3.verse: He asked, “What can I do for you? How can I make up for the harm done so you can bless the LORD’s people?”

4.verse: The Gibeonites said to David, “We cannot demand silver or gold from Saul or his family. And we don’t have the right to kill anyone in Israel.” Then David asked, “What do you want me to do for you?”

5.verse: The Gibeonites said, “Saul made plans against us and tried to destroy all our people who are left in the land of Israel.

6.verse: So bring seven of his sons to us. Then we will kill them and hang them on stakes in the presence of the LORD at Gibeah, the hometown of Saul, the LORD’s chosen king.” The king said, “I will give them to you.”

7.verse: But the king protected Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the promise he had made to Jonathan in the LORD’s name.

8.verse: The king did take Armoni and Mephibosheth, sons of Rizpah and Saul. (Rizpah was the daughter of Aiah.) And the king took the five sons of Saul’s daughter Merab. (Adriel son of Barzillai the Meholathite was the father of Merab’s five sons.)

9.verse: David gave these seven sons to the Gibeonites. Then the Gibeonites killed them and hung them on stakes on a hill in the presence of the LORD. All seven sons died together. They were put to death during the first days of the harvest season at the beginning of barley harvest.

10.verse: Aiah’s daughter Rizpah took the rough cloth that was worn to show sadness and put it on a rock for herself. She stayed there from the beginning of the harvest until the rain fell on her sons’ bodies. During the day she did not let the birds of the sky touch her sons’ bodies, and during the night she did not let the wild animals touch them.

11.verse: People told David what Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, Saul’s slave woman, was doing.

12.verse: Then David took the bones of Saul and Jonathan from the men of Jabesh Gilead. (The Philistines had hung the bodies of Saul and Jonathan in the public square of Beth Shan after they had killed Saul at Gilboa. Later the men of Jabesh Gilead had secretly taken them from there.)

13.verse: David brought the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from Gilead. Then the people gathered the bodies of Saul’s seven sons who were hanged on stakes.

14.verse: The people buried the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan at Zela in Benjamin in the tomb of Saul’s father Kish. The people did everything the king commanded. Then God answered the prayers for the land.

15.verse: Wars with the Philistines - Again there was war between the Philistines and Israel. David and his men went out to fight the Philistines, but David became tired.

16.verse: Ishbi-Benob, one of the sons of Rapha, had a bronze spearhead weighing about seven and one-half pounds and a new sword. He planned to kill David,

17.verse: but Abishai son of Zeruiah killed the Philistine and saved David’s life. Then David’s men made a promise to him, saying, “Never again will you go out with us to battle. If you were killed, Israel would lose its greatest leader.”

18.verse: Later, at Gob, there was another battle with the Philistines. Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, another one of the sons of Rapha.

19.verse: Later, there was another battle at Gob with the Philistines. Elhanan son of Jaare-Oregim from Bethlehem killed Goliath from Gath. His spear was as large as a weaver’s rod.

20.verse: At Gath another battle took place. A huge man was there; he had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four fingers and toes in all. This man also was one of the sons of Rapha.

21.verse: When he challenged Israel, Jonathan son of Shimeah, David’s brother, killed him.

22.verse: These four sons of Rapha from Gath were killed by David and his men.

1.verse: David’s Song of Praise - David sang this song to the LORD when the LORD saved him from Saul and all his other enemies.

2.verse: He said: “The LORD is my rock, my fortress, my Savior.

3.verse: My God is my rock. I can run to him for safety. He is my shield and my saving strength, my defender and my place of safety. The LORD saves me from those who want to harm me.

4.verse: I will call to the LORD, who is worthy of praise, and I will be saved from my enemies.

5.verse: “The waves of death came around me; the deadly rivers overwhelmed me.

6.verse: The ropes of death wrapped around me. The traps of death were before me.

7.verse: In my trouble I called to the LORD; I cried out to my God. From his temple he heard my voice; my call for help reached his ears.

8.verse: “The earth trembled and shook. The foundations of heaven began to shake. They trembled because the LORD was angry.

9.verse: Smoke came out of his nose, and burning fire came out of his mouth. Burning coals went before him.

10.verse: He tore open the sky and came down with dark clouds under his feet.

11.verse: He rode a creature with wings and flew. He raced on the wings of the wind.

12.verse: He made darkness his shelter, surrounded by fog and clouds.

13.verse: Out of the brightness of his presence came flashes of lightning.

14.verse: The LORD thundered from heaven; the Most High raised his voice.

15.verse: He shot his arrows and scattered his enemies. His bolts of lightning confused them with fear.

16.verse: The LORD spoke strongly. The wind blew from his nose. Then the valleys of the sea appeared, and the foundations of the earth were seen.

17.verse: “The LORD reached down from above and took me; he pulled me from the deep water.

18.verse: He saved me from my powerful enemies, from those who hated me, because they were too strong for me.

19.verse: They attacked me at my time of trouble, but the LORD supported me.

20.verse: He took me to a safe place. Because he delights in me, he saved me.

21.verse: “The LORD spared me because I did what was right. Because I have not done evil, he has rewarded me.

22.verse: I have followed the ways of the LORD; I have not done evil by turning from my God.

23.verse: I remember all his laws and have not broken his rules.

24.verse: I am innocent before him; I have kept myself from doing evil.

25.verse: The LORD rewarded me because I did what was right, because I did what the LORD said was right.

26.verse: “LORD, you are loyal to those who are loyal, and you are good to those who are good.

27.verse: You are pure to those who are pure, but you are against those who are evil.

28.verse: You save the humble, but you bring down those who are proud.

29.verse: LORD, you give light to my lamp. The LORD brightens the darkness around me.

30.verse: With your help I can attack an army. With God’s help I can jump over a wall.

31.verse: “The ways of God are without fault; the LORD’s words are pure. He is a shield to those who trust him.

32.verse: Who is God? Only the LORD. Who is the Rock? Only our God.

33.verse: God is my protection. He makes my way free from fault.

34.verse: He makes me like a deer that does not stumble; he helps me stand on the steep mountains.

35.verse: He trains my hands for battle so my arms can bend a bronze bow.

36.verse: You protect me with your saving shield. You have stooped to make me great.

37.verse: You give me a better way to live, so I live as you want me to.

38.verse: I chased my enemies and destroyed them. I did not quit till they were destroyed.

39.verse: I destroyed and crushed them so they couldn’t rise up again. They fell beneath my feet.

40.verse: You gave me strength in battle. You made my enemies bow before me.

41.verse: You made my enemies turn back, and I destroyed those who hated me.

42.verse: They called for help, but no one came to save them. They called to the LORD, but he did not answer them.

43.verse: I beat my enemies into pieces, like dust on the ground. I poured them out and walked on them like mud in the streets.

44.verse: “You saved me when my people attacked me. You kept me as the leader of nations. People I never knew serve me.

45.verse: Foreigners obey me. As soon as they hear me, they obey me.

46.verse: They all become afraid and tremble in their hiding places.

47.verse: “The LORD lives! May my Rock be praised! Praise God, the Rock, who saves me!

48.verse: God gives me victory over my enemies and brings people under my rule.

49.verse: He frees me from my enemies. “You set me over those who hate me. You saved me from violent people.

50.verse: So I will praise you, LORD, among the nations. I will sing praises to your name.

51.verse: The LORD gives great victories to his king. He is loyal to his appointed king, to David and his descendants forever.”

1.verse: David’s Last Words - These are the last words of David. This is the message of David son of Jesse. The man made great by the Most High God speaks. He is the appointed king of the God of Jacob; he is the sweet singer of Israel:

2.verse: “The LORD’s Spirit spoke through me, and his word was on my tongue.

3.verse: The God of Israel spoke; the Rock of Israel said to me: ‘Whoever rules fairly over people, who rules with respect for God,

4.verse: is like the morning light at dawn, like a morning without clouds. He is like sunshine after a rain that makes the grass sprout from the ground.’

5.verse: “This is how God has cared for my family. God made a lasting agreement with me, right and sure in every way. He will accomplish my salvation and satisfy all my desires.

6.verse: “But all evil people will be thrown away like thorns that cannot be held in a hand.

7.verse: No one can touch them except with a tool of iron or wood. They will be thrown in the fire and burned where they lie.”

8.verse: David’s Army - These are the names of David’s warriors: Josheb-Basshebeth, the Tahkemonite, was head of the Three. He killed eight hundred men at one time.

9.verse: Next was Eleazar son of Dodai the Ahohite. Eleazar was one of the three soldiers who were with David when they challenged the Philistines. The Philistines were gathered for battle, and the Israelites drew back.

10.verse: But Eleazar stayed where he was and fought the Philistines until he was so tired his hand stuck to his sword. The LORD gave a great victory for the Israelites that day. The troops came back after Eleazar had won the battle, but only to take weapons and armor from the enemy.

11.verse: Next there was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines came together to fight in a vegetable field. Israel’s troops ran away from the Philistines,

12.verse: but Shammah stood in the middle of the field and fought for it and killed the Philistines. And the LORD gave a great victory.

13.verse: Once, three of the Thirty, David’s chief soldiers, came down to him at the cave of Adullam during harvest. The Philistine army had camped in the Valley of Rephaim.

14.verse: At that time David was in the stronghold, and some of the Philistines were in Bethlehem.

15.verse: David had a strong desire for some water. He said, “Oh, I wish someone would get me water from the well near the city gate of Bethlehem!”

16.verse: So the three warriors broke through the Philistine army and took water from the well near the city gate of Bethlehem. Then they brought it to David, but he refused to drink it. He poured it out before the LORD,

17.verse: saying, “May the LORD keep me from drinking this water! It would be like drinking the blood of the men who risked their lives!” So David refused to drink it. These were the brave things that the three warriors did.

18.verse: Abishai, brother of Joab son of Zeruiah, was captain of the Three. Abishai fought three hundred soldiers with his spear and killed them. He became as famous as the Three

19.verse: and was more honored than the Three. He became their commander even though he was not one of them.

20.verse: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was a brave fighter from Kabzeel who did mighty things. He killed two of the best warriors from Moab. He also went down into a pit and killed a lion on a snowy day.

21.verse: Benaiah killed a large Egyptian who had a spear in his hand. Benaiah had a club, but he grabbed the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.

22.verse: These were the things Benaiah son of Jehoiada did. He was as famous as the Three.

23.verse: He received more honor than the Thirty, but he did not become a member of the Three. David made him leader of his bodyguards.

24.verse: The Thirty Chief Soldiers - The following men were among the Thirty: Asahel brother of Joab; Elhanan son of Dodo from Bethlehem;

25.verse: Shammah the Harodite; Elika the Harodite;

26.verse: Helez the Paltite; Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa;

27.verse: Abiezer the Anathothite; Mebunnai the Hushathite;

28.verse: Zalmon the Ahohite; Maharai the Netophathite;

29.verse: Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite; Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah in Benjamin;

30.verse: Benaiah the Pirathonite; Hiddai from the ravines of Gaash;

31.verse: Abi-Albon the Arbathite; Azmaveth the Barhumite;

32.verse: Eliahba the Shaalbonite; the sons of Jashen; Jonathan

33.verse: son of Shammah the Hararite; Ahiam son of Sharar the Hararite;

34.verse: Eliphelet son of Ahasbai the Maacathite; Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite;

35.verse: Hezro the Carmelite; Paarai the Arbite;

36.verse: Igal son of Nathan of Zobah; the son of Hagri;

37.verse: Zelek the Ammonite; Naharai the Beerothite, who carried the armor of Joab son of Zeruiah;

38.verse: Ira the Ithrite; Gareb the Ithrite,

39.verse: and Uriah the Hittite. There were thirty-seven in all.

1.verse: David Counts His Army - The LORD was angry with Israel again, and he caused David to turn against the Israelites. He said, “Go, count the people of Israel and Judah.”

2.verse: So King David said to Joab, the commander of the army, “Go through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, and count the people. Then I will know how many there are.”

3.verse: But Joab said to the king, “May the LORD your God give you a hundred times more people, and may my master the king live to see this happen. Why do you want to do this?”

4.verse: But the king commanded Joab and the commanders of the army, so they left the king to count the Israelites.

5.verse: After crossing the Jordan River, they camped near Aroer on the south side of the city in the ravine. They went through Gad and on to Jazer.

6.verse: Then they went to Gilead and the land of Tahtim Hodshi and to Dan Jaan and around to Sidon.

7.verse: They went to the strong, walled city of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites. Finally, they went to southern Judah, to Beersheba.

8.verse: After nine months and twenty days, they had gone through all the land. Then they came back to Jerusalem.

9.verse: Joab gave the list of the people to the king. There were eight hundred thousand men in Israel who could use the sword and five hundred thousand men in Judah.

10.verse: David felt ashamed after he had counted the people. He said to the LORD, “I have sinned greatly by what I have done. LORD, I beg you to forgive me, your servant, because I have been very foolish.”

11.verse: When David got up in the morning, the LORD spoke his word to Gad, who was a prophet and David’s seer.

12.verse: The LORD told Gad, “Go and tell David, ‘This is what the LORD says: I offer you three choices. Choose one of them and I will do it to you.’”

13.verse: So Gad went to David and said to him, “Should three years of hunger come to you and your land? Or should your enemies chase you for three months? Or should there be three days of disease in your land? Think about it. Then decide which of these things I should tell the LORD who sent me.”

14.verse: David said to Gad, “I am in great trouble. Let the LORD punish us, because the LORD is very merciful. Don’t let my punishment come from human beings!”

15.verse: So the LORD sent a terrible disease on Israel. It began in the morning and continued until the chosen time to stop. From Dan to Beersheba seventy thousand people died.

16.verse: When the angel raised his arm toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the LORD felt very sorry about the terrible things that had happened. He said to the angel who was destroying the people, “That is enough! Put down your arm!” The angel of the LORD was then by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

17.verse: When David saw the angel that killed the people, he said to the LORD, “I am the one who sinned and did wrong. These people only followed me like sheep. They did nothing wrong. Please punish me and my family.”

18.verse: That day Gad came to David and said, “Go and build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”

19.verse: So David did what Gad told him to do, just as the LORD commanded.

20.verse: Araunah looked and saw the king and his servants coming to him. So he went out and bowed facedown on the ground before the king.

21.verse: He said, “Why has my master the king come to me?” David answered, “To buy the threshing floor from you so I can build an altar to the LORD. Then the terrible disease will stop.”

22.verse: Araunah said to David, “My master and king, you may take anything you want for a sacrifice. Here are some oxen for the whole burnt offering and the threshing boards and the yokes for the wood.

23.verse: My king, I give everything to you.” Araunah also said to the king, “May the LORD your God be pleased with you.”

24.verse: But the king answered Araunah, “No, I will pay you for the land. I won’t offer to the LORD my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for one and one-fourth pounds of silver.

25.verse: He built an altar to the LORD there and offered whole burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. Then the LORD answered his prayer for the country, and the disease in Israel stopped.
